articles.title: UN Rights Council Creates Afghanistan Accountability Body
articles.summary:

Over the previous year, UN experts and countries from various regions joined civil society groups appealing to the EU to take this step.The investigative mechanism, in accordance with its mandate and the practice of two similar mechanisms on Syria and Myanmar, is expected to take a comprehensive approach to investigating international crimes. articles.content:
Click to expand Image The United Nations Human Rights Council, Geneva, Switzerland, February 26, 2024. © 2024 Hannes Albert/picture-alliance/dpa/AP Photo

(Geneva) – The United Nations Human Rights Council on October 6, 2025, adopted a landmark resolution creating an independent mechanism to investigate past and ongoing rights abuses in Afghanistan, Human Rights Watch said today. The resolution puts the Taliban and all others responsible for serious crimes in Afghanistan on notice that evidence is being collected and prepared so they may someday face justice.

The resolution, led by the European Union, was adopted by consensus. The mechanism is expected to include a focus on the Taliban’s current abuses against women and girls, which amount to gender persecution. The body will collect and preserve evidence of war crimes, crimes against humanity, and other grave rights abuses; identify individuals responsible; and prepare files that can be used to support their prosecution in national and international courts. The resolution also further extended the mandate of the UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in Afghanistan, whose monitoring and reporting remains essential and is complementary to the work of the new mechanism.

“Countries at the UN Human Rights Council have together sent a strong message of their resolve to ensure that those responsible for serious international crimes in Afghanistan now or in the past will one day face justice in court,” said Fereshta Abbasi, Afghanistan researcher at Human Rights Watch. “It’s crucial for the new mechanism to get up and running quickly so that it can begin to collect, prepare, and preserve evidence, and build files on those responsible for international crimes in Afghanistan.”

The resolution responds to calls by Afghan and international human rights groups to address entrenched impunity in Afghanistan. In August 2025, a coalition led by HRD+, a network of Afghan human rights defenders, with support from 108 Afghan and international organizations, reissued an appeal for the investigative mechanism after four years of campaigning. Over the previous year, UN experts and countries from various regions joined civil society groups appealing to the EU to take this step.

The investigative mechanism, in accordance with its mandate and the practice of two similar mechanisms on Syria and Myanmar, is expected to take a comprehensive approach to investigating international crimes. All individuals responsible for carrying out rights-abusive Taliban edicts and policies that violate international law, such as the Propagation of Virtue and Prevention of Vice law, would be subject to investigation, and the evidence will be collected, preserved, and prepared for future prosecutions.

The mechanism is expected to investigate actions by the Taliban leadership, provincial directors, governors, and other officials who are responsible, for example, for torture and other ill-treatment of people in custody. It will also target officials responsible for the denial of women and girls of their rights, notably to education, health care, and freedom of movement, which constitutes gender persecution.

The investigative mechanism’s scope is not limited to Taliban abuses but also covers those by officials of the former government, warlords, and members of international forces, non-state armed groups, and others responsible for serious abuses and violations in Afghanistan.

“The European Union has demonstrated principled leadership by putting forward this resolution for an investigative mechanism on Afghanistan,” Abbasi said. “By adopting the resolution by consensus, UN Human Rights Council member states have sent a powerful message against double standards for justice or a hierarchy of victims, and demonstrated growing international resolve to bring those responsible for international crimes to account.”

The UN secretary-general has been asked to put the body in operation with some urgency, finding a way to ensure that it can begin work on its core mandate despite the UN’s ongoing financial crisis. This is particularly urgent for women and girls, whose lives are so restricted every day in many ways under Taliban rule.

The International Criminal Court (ICC) has issued arrest warrants for two senior Taliban officials on charges of the crime against humanity of gender persecution. The resolution directs the new mechanism to cooperate closely with the ICC and, particularly in light of US sanctions imposed on its officials and those seeking justice before the court, condemns “attacks and threats against the Court, elected officials, personnel and those cooperating with the Court.”

“UN Human Rights Council members have sent a clear message to victims, their families, and all those bravely fighting for justice in Afghanistan that their voices have been heard, and that their suffering is neither invisible nor erasable,” Abbasi said. “The UN secretary-general should ensure the investigative mechanism is promptly rolled out, and UN member states should ensure funding is made available for the mechanism to begin its work.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports the UN Human Rights Council's adoption of a resolution to create an independent investigative mechanism for serious human rights abuses in Afghanistan, including gender persecution by the Taliban. This represents a significant, broad, and meaningful step toward accountability and justice for victims, with international consensus and detailed plans for evidence collection and prosecution. The mechanism addresses entrenched impunity and supports the rights of women and girls, offering hope for future justice and human rights protection.
articles.personality_title: UN creates new body to investigate human rights abuses in Afghanistan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Afghanistan has faced serious human rights abuses for many years, especially under Taliban rule. Women and girls have been severely restricted in their rights, and many crimes have gone unpunished.

**What happened** – On October 6, 2025, the United Nations Human Rights Council agreed to set up an independent group to investigate these abuses. This new mechanism will collect evidence of war crimes and crimes against humanity, focusing on the Taliban’s treatment of women and girls. It will work to identify those responsible and prepare files that could help bring them to court.

**Impact** – This is a major step because it shows the world’s determination to hold the Taliban and others accountable. Unlike before, when many crimes were ignored, this mechanism will gather proof carefully to support future trials. It also covers abuses by other groups and officials, not just the Taliban. This gives victims and their families a clearer path to justice.

**What's next step** – The UN secretary-general has been asked to start this mechanism quickly, even though the UN faces money problems. The new body will also work closely with the International Criminal Court, which already has arrest warrants for some Taliban leaders. Funding and support from UN countries will be important to get this work going.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The UN has launched a new independent group to investigate serious crimes in Afghanistan, aiming to bring justice for victims and hold abusers accountable.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’ONU crée un nouvel organe pour enquêter sur les violations des droits en Afghanistan
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Afghanistan a connu de graves violations des droits humains pendant de nombreuses années, surtout sous le régime taliban. Les droits des femmes et des filles ont été fortement restreints, et de nombreux crimes sont restés impunis.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 6 octobre 2025, le Conseil des droits de l’homme des Nations Unies a accepté de créer un groupe indépendant pour enquêter sur ces abus. Ce mécanisme collectera des preuves de crimes de guerre et de crimes contre l’humanité, en se concentrant sur le traitement réservé par les talibans aux femmes et aux filles. Il identifiera les responsables et préparera des dossiers pour aider à les traduire en justice.

**Impact** – C’est une avancée importante car elle montre la volonté mondiale de tenir les talibans et d’autres responsables pour compte. Contrairement au passé où beaucoup de crimes étaient ignorés, ce mécanisme rassemblera des preuves solides pour soutenir de futurs procès. Il couvrira aussi les abus d’autres groupes et responsables. Cela offre aux victimes et à leurs familles une voie plus claire vers la justice.

**Prochaine étape** – Le secrétaire général de l’ONU a été chargé de lancer rapidement ce mécanisme, malgré les problèmes financiers de l’ONU. Le groupe travaillera en étroite collaboration avec la Cour pénale internationale, qui a déjà émis des mandats d’arrêt contre certains dirigeants talibans. Le financement et le soutien des pays membres seront essentiels pour démarrer ce travail.

**Une phrase clé** – L’ONU a lancé un nouveau groupe indépendant pour enquêter sur les crimes graves en Afghanistan, afin d’apporter justice aux victimes et de tenir les coupables responsables.
articles.personality_title_es: La ONU crea un nuevo organismo para investigar abusos de derechos en Afganistán
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Afganistán ha sufrido graves abusos de derechos humanos durante muchos años, especialmente bajo el control de los talibanes. Los derechos de mujeres y niñas han sido muy limitados, y muchos crímenes no han sido castigados.

**Qué pasó** – El 6 de octubre de 2025, el Consejo de Derechos Humanos de la ONU acordó crear un grupo independiente para investigar estos abusos. Este mecanismo recopilará pruebas de crímenes de guerra y crímenes de lesa humanidad, enfocándose en el trato que los talibanes dan a mujeres y niñas. Identificará a los responsables y preparará documentos para ayudar a llevarlos a juicio.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque muestra la determinación mundial de responsabilizar a los talibanes y otros culpables. Antes, muchos crímenes eran ignorados, pero ahora este mecanismo reunirá pruebas para respaldar futuros juicios. También cubrirá abusos de otros grupos y funcionarios. Esto da a las víctimas y sus familias un camino más claro hacia la justicia.

**Próximo paso** – Se ha pedido al secretario general de la ONU que ponga en marcha este mecanismo rápidamente, a pesar de los problemas financieros de la ONU. El nuevo grupo trabajará cerca de la Corte Penal Internacional, que ya tiene órdenes de arresto contra algunos líderes talibanes. Será importante que los países miembros apoyen y financien este trabajo.

**Una frase clave** – La ONU ha creado un nuevo grupo independiente para investigar crímenes graves en Afganistán, con el objetivo de lograr justicia para las víctimas y responsabilizar a los abusadores.

articles.title: In landmark labour case, UN World Court weighs in on right to strike
articles.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) opened hearings on Monday to determine whether the right to strike is protected under international law – the first time the world’s top court has been asked to weigh in on the balance between workers’ rights and employers’ interests.
articles.content:
The case stems from a 2023 request by the Governing Body of the International Labour Organization (ILO), which asked the Court for an advisory opinion on whether the Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948 (No. 87) includes the right to strike.

Adopted in the aftermath of World War Two, Convention 87 is a cornerstone of international labour law, guaranteeing workers and employers the right to form and join organizations of their choosing. It does not explicitly mention strikes, but advocates have long interpreted freedom of association to include that right.

ICJ President Yūji Iwasawa began Monday’s proceedings by reading the formal question to the judges, referencing the ILO’s resolution and the Court’s procedural authority. He noted the “tripartite structure of the ILO, which is comprised of representatives of governments, employers and workers.”

A rare request

Tomi Kohiyama, ILO Legal Adviser, recalled that the ILO had not appeared before the ICJ in a consultative capacity since 1932, underscoring the rarity of such requests.

She said the ILO secretariat would not take a position on subject but would assist the Court by clarifying institutional context and interpretative approaches under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties.

“The participation of organisations of employers and workers ... is without precedent in the history of your august institution,” she added, referring to the ILO’s tripartite nature.

Three voices of ILO

Founded in 1919, the ILO is unique within the UN system for its tripartite structure, bringing together representatives of governments, employers and workers to set international labour standards.

That balance, however, has sometimes led to deadlock – most notably in 2012, when employer groups challenged whether Conventions No. 87 and 98 recognize a right to strike.

Steiner SA The headquarters building of the International Labour Organization (ILO) in Geneva.

Arguments from labour and business

Paapa Danquah, speaking for the International Trade Union Confederation (ITUC), described strikes as a timeless expression of collective action.

“Strike action has been our vital tool … to improve labour conditions and to defend our human dignities,” he told the court.

He argued that the right to strike is inherently part of freedom of association and thus should be recognized as protected under Convention No. 87.

In contrast, Roberto Suárez Santos, on behalf of the International Organisation of Employers (IOE), asserted that while the right to strike is not objectionable in principle, Convention No. 87 neither explicitly nor implicitly covers the right to strike.

He warned that to read it into the Convention now would impose a prescriptive regime – defining modalities of strike – that could disrupt nuanced national labour systems.

He expressed that the proper path would be consensus within the ILO’s tripartite bodies, not unilateral judicial elevation of standards.

ICJ advisory opinions

Over three days of hearings, 21 countries and organizations are expected to take the stand, with 31 written statements already filed in the ICJ Registry – reflecting global interest in the outcome.

The Court’s advisory opinion, expected in the coming months, will not be legally binding but could profoundly influence international and national labour law.
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the International Court of Justice considering a landmark case on whether the right to strike is protected under international law, which has broad implications for workers' rights globally. This is a significant development in international labor law with potential to influence many countries and improve labor conditions, reflecting a meaningful and substantive advancement in human rights.
articles.personality_title: World Court considers if striking is an international right
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The International Labour Organization (ILO) asked the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in 2023 to give advice on whether the right to strike is protected by an important 1948 labour law treaty called Convention No. 87. This treaty guarantees workers and employers the freedom to form groups, but it does not clearly say if striking is allowed.

**What happened** – On Monday, the ICJ began hearings to answer this question for the first time ever. Representatives from governments, employers, and workers spoke about the issue. The International Trade Union Confederation said striking is a key way workers can protect their rights, while the International Organisation of Employers warned that the treaty does not clearly include a right to strike and changes should happen through agreement, not court decisions.

**Impact** – This case is special because it is the first time the top UN court has been asked to balance workers’ right to strike against employers’ concerns. The court’s opinion won’t be legally binding, but it could influence many countries and how they protect workers’ rights. It may help clarify international labour laws and support fairer work conditions worldwide.

**What's next step** – Over three days, 21 countries and organizations will give their views, with many written statements already submitted. The ICJ will give its advisory opinion in the next few months. This opinion could guide future discussions and decisions about workers’ rights and labour laws around the world.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The International Court of Justice is examining for the first time whether the right to strike is protected by international law, a decision that could shape workers’ rights globally.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Cour mondiale examine si le droit de grève est un droit international
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2023, l’Organisation internationale du travail (OIT) a demandé à la Cour internationale de Justice (CIJ) si le droit de grève est protégé par une importante convention de 1948, la Convention n° 87. Cette convention garantit la liberté d’association pour les travailleurs et employeurs, mais ne précise pas clairement si la grève est autorisée.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, la CIJ a commencé les audiences pour répondre à cette question pour la première fois. Des représentants des gouvernements, des employeurs et des travailleurs ont pris la parole. La Confédération syndicale internationale a expliqué que la grève est un moyen essentiel pour les travailleurs de défendre leurs droits, tandis que l’Organisation internationale des employeurs a souligné que la convention ne couvre pas clairement ce droit et que les changements doivent venir d’accords, pas de décisions judiciaires.

**Impact** – Cette affaire est unique car c’est la première fois que la plus haute cour de l’ONU doit équilibrer le droit de grève des travailleurs et les préoccupations des employeurs. L’avis de la cour ne sera pas contraignant, mais pourrait influencer de nombreux pays et la manière dont ils protègent les droits des travailleurs. Cela pourrait clarifier les lois internationales du travail et soutenir des conditions de travail plus justes dans le monde.

**Prochaines étapes** – Pendant trois jours, 21 pays et organisations donneront leur avis, avec de nombreuses déclarations écrites déjà déposées. La CIJ rendra son avis consultatif dans les prochains mois. Cet avis pourrait guider les futures discussions et décisions sur les droits des travailleurs et les lois du travail dans le monde.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La Cour internationale de Justice étudie pour la première fois si le droit de grève est protégé par le droit international, une décision qui pourrait influencer les droits des travailleurs à l’échelle mondiale.
articles.personality_title_es: La Corte Mundial analiza si la huelga es un derecho internacional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2023, la Organización Internacional del Trabajo (OIT) pidió a la Corte Internacional de Justicia (CIJ) que diera su opinión sobre si el derecho a la huelga está protegido por un tratado laboral importante de 1948 llamado Convenio No. 87. Este tratado garantiza la libertad para que trabajadores y empleadores formen grupos, pero no dice claramente si se permite la huelga.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, la CIJ inició audiencias para responder esta pregunta por primera vez. Representantes de gobiernos, empleadores y trabajadores expresaron sus opiniones. La Confederación Sindical Internacional dijo que la huelga es una forma clave para que los trabajadores defiendan sus derechos, mientras que la Organización Internacional de Empleadores advirtió que el tratado no incluye claramente el derecho a huelga y que los cambios deben hacerse por acuerdo, no por decisión judicial.

**Impacto** – Este caso es especial porque es la primera vez que el máximo tribunal de la ONU debe equilibrar el derecho a la huelga de los trabajadores con las preocupaciones de los empleadores. La opinión de la corte no será legalmente vinculante, pero podría influir en muchos países y en cómo protegen los derechos de los trabajadores. Puede ayudar a aclarar las leyes laborales internacionales y apoyar condiciones laborales más justas en todo el mundo.

**Próximo paso** – Durante tres días, 21 países y organizaciones presentarán sus puntos de vista, con muchas declaraciones escritas ya entregadas. La CIJ emitirá su opinión consultiva en los próximos meses. Esta opinión podría guiar futuras discusiones y decisiones sobre los derechos laborales en todo el mundo.

**Frase clave** – La Corte Internacional de Justicia examina por primera vez si el derecho a la huelga está protegido por el derecho internacional, una decisión que podría moldear los derechos de los trabajadores a nivel global.

articles.title: Austria for qualified majority in the EU accession process
articles.summary: Austria's government advocates for making the decision on the admission of new EU member states by qualified majority. The government in Vienna aims to expedite the accession of the Western Balkan countries. The European Minister of the Alpine Republic is traveling through the region this week in this context.
articles.content:
Austria’s government advocates for making the decision on the admission of new EU member states by qualified majority. The government in Vienna aims to expedite the accession of the Western Balkan countries. The European Minister of the Alpine Republic is traveling through the region this week in this context.

Skopje/Prishtina (APA) – The Austrian Minister for Europe Claudia Plakolm held a working meeting in Skopje with the North Macedonian Minister for Europe Orhan Murtezani and the Slovenian State Secretary for Europe Neva Grašič. “Austria will advocate for a qualified majority in the accession process,” emphasized Plakolm’s spokesperson on Monday to APA. “For over 20 years, we have been hanging on the promise that North Macedonia will become part of the EU,” Plakolm stated.

The politician from the conservative ruling party ÖVP further pointed out that Austria and North Macedonia are connected by close economic and human relations. More than 27,000 North Macedonians have found a new home in Austria, and at the same time, Austria is the largest investor in North Macedonia. “One only has to look at the map to see that a large piece is missing in the middle of Europe (in the European Union, note), and that is the countries of the Western Balkans.”

Further travel to Kosovo

After the meeting with her counterpart, Plakolm planned a one-on-one discussion with Foreign Minister Timčo Mucunski. The visit in Skopje will conclude with a company visit to the energy provider EVN Makedonija (a subsidiary of the Austrian EVN Group), which will also be attended by the energy minister of the host country, Sanja Bozhinovska. Afterwards, they will continue by car to the capital of Kosovo, Prishtina. The Slovenian State Secretary for Europe will also accompany the Austrian minister there. They will start with a working meeting with Besnik Bislimi, the Deputy Prime Minister of Kosovo.

Plakolm will also visit an initiative of the Austrian Development Agency (ADA) in Lipjan. There, the ADA supports particularly disadvantaged youth. Following that, an exchange with the head of the EU rule of law mission EULEX, Giovanni Pietro Barbano, is planned, after which there will be a meeting with President Vjosa Osmani. Plakolm will also meet representatives of Austrian companies and civil society. After a short stop in Vienna, the minister will travel on Tuesday to the Montenegrin capital Podgorica, making it the third country in her six-country tour in six days.

Government and population at odds

With her trip, Plakolm follows in the footsteps of former Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz (ÖVP), who, in early 2016, also visited all EU candidate countries of the Western Balkans in six days as Foreign Minister. Ten years later, the same states are still waiting for EU membership, but at least two of them – Montenegro and Albania – can hope for full membership before 2030. For the other four, this is still a distant prospect for various reasons.

The Austrian government is one of the strongest advocates for a rapid EU membership of the Western Balkan states, but it also has to do some convincing at home. The Austrian population views EU enlargement with particular skepticism compared to other European countries. (6.10.2025)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Austria's government advocating for a qualified majority decision process to expedite the EU accession of Western Balkan countries, which represents a significant political effort to promote regional integration, stability, and economic development. This has broad positive implications for many people in multiple countries, fostering cooperation, economic ties, and potentially improved governance and human rights conditions in the Western Balkans. The article provides sufficient context about the political process, key actors, and the scope of the initiative, making it a substantive and meaningful story.
articles.personality_title: Austria pushes for faster EU membership decisions for Western Balkans
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Joining the European Union (EU) is a long process that new countries must go through before becoming members. Currently, every EU country must agree for a new member to join, which can slow things down. The Western Balkans, a group of countries in Southeast Europe, have been waiting many years to join the EU.

**What happened** – Austria’s government wants to change the decision-making to a “qualified majority” vote. This means new countries can join if most EU members agree, not necessarily all. Austria’s European Minister, Claudia Plakolm, visited several Western Balkan countries like North Macedonia and Kosovo to support this idea and meet local leaders and businesses.

**Impact** – This change could speed up the process for Western Balkan countries to become EU members. It is important because many people from these countries live and work in Austria, and Austria invests a lot in the region. Faster membership could bring more economic opportunities, better laws, and closer ties between these countries and the rest of Europe.

**What’s next step** – Austria will continue to discuss this plan with other EU countries. Minister Plakolm is visiting more Western Balkan countries to build support. If enough EU countries agree, the rule could change, making it easier and quicker for more countries to join the EU.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Austria is leading efforts to speed up EU membership for Western Balkan countries by supporting a new voting rule that requires fewer countries to agree.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’Autriche milite pour accélérer l’adhésion des Balkans occidentaux à l’UE
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Rejoindre l’Union européenne (UE) est un long processus qui nécessite l’accord de tous les pays membres, ce qui peut ralentir les choses. Les Balkans occidentaux, un groupe de pays en Europe du Sud-Est, attendent depuis de nombreuses années pour devenir membres de l’UE.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le gouvernement autrichien souhaite changer la prise de décision en adoptant le vote à la « majorité qualifiée ». Cela signifie que de nouveaux pays peuvent rejoindre l’UE si la plupart des membres sont d’accord, pas forcément tous. La ministre autrichienne pour l’Europe, Claudia Plakolm, a visité plusieurs pays des Balkans occidentaux comme la Macédoine du Nord et le Kosovo pour soutenir cette idée et rencontrer des responsables locaux et des entreprises.

**Impact** – Ce changement pourrait accélérer le processus d’adhésion des pays des Balkans occidentaux. C’est important car beaucoup de personnes de ces pays vivent et travaillent en Autriche, et l’Autriche investit beaucoup dans la région. Une adhésion plus rapide pourrait apporter plus d’opportunités économiques, de meilleures lois et des liens plus étroits entre ces pays et le reste de l’Europe.

**Prochaines étapes** – L’Autriche va continuer à discuter de ce projet avec les autres pays de l’UE. La ministre Plakolm visite d’autres pays des Balkans occidentaux pour rassembler du soutien. Si suffisamment de pays de l’UE sont d’accord, la règle pourrait changer, rendant plus facile et plus rapide l’adhésion de nouveaux membres.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’Autriche mène des efforts pour accélérer l’adhésion des Balkans occidentaux à l’UE en soutenant une nouvelle règle de vote nécessitant moins d’accords.
articles.personality_title_es: Austria impulsa acelerar la adhesión de los Balcanes Occidentales a la UE
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Unirse a la Unión Europea (UE) es un proceso largo que requiere la aprobación de todos los países miembros, lo que puede retrasar el ingreso de nuevos países. Los Balcanes Occidentales, un grupo de países en el sureste de Europa, llevan muchos años esperando para ser miembros de la UE.

**Qué pasó** – El gobierno de Austria quiere cambiar la forma de decidir a una votación por “mayoría cualificada”. Esto significa que un nuevo país puede unirse si la mayoría de los miembros están de acuerdo, no todos. La ministra europea de Austria, Claudia Plakolm, visitó varios países de los Balcanes Occidentales como Macedonia del Norte y Kosovo para apoyar esta idea y reunirse con líderes locales y empresas.

**Impacto** – Este cambio podría acelerar el proceso para que los países de los Balcanes Occidentales se conviertan en miembros de la UE. Es importante porque muchas personas de estos países viven y trabajan en Austria, y Austria invierte mucho en la región. Una adhesión más rápida podría traer más oportunidades económicas, mejores leyes y vínculos más cercanos con el resto de Europa.

**Próximo paso** – Austria continuará hablando con otros países de la UE sobre este plan. La ministra Plakolm visitará más países de los Balcanes Occidentales para conseguir apoyo. Si suficientes países de la UE están de acuerdo, la regla podría cambiar, haciendo que sea más fácil y rápido unirse a la UE.

**Resumen en una frase** – Austria lidera esfuerzos para acelerar la adhesión de los Balcanes Occidentales a la UE apoyando una nueva regla de votación que requiere menos acuerdos.

articles.title: UNESCO board selects Egypt's former antiquities minister El-Enany as new chief
articles.summary: UNESCO is set to appoint Egypt's Khaled El-Enany as its new director general, according to diplomatic sources. The cultural agency's executive board on Monday voted 55 to 2 in favor of Egypt's former tourism and antiquities minister, whose name will be put forward for approval to UNESCO's members in November.
articles.content:
Khaled El-Enany, former Minister of Tourism and Antiquities of Egypt and candidate to become the head of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) poses during a photo session in Paris on October 1, 2025.

The UN culture agency's executive board on Monday voted to appoint a former Egyptian minister as the agency's next chief, the board's chair said, as UNESCO grapples with accusations of bias and the United States' withdrawal from the organisation.

UNESCO's board backed former Egyptian antiquities and tourism minister Khaled el-Enany to replace outgoing French director-general Audrey Azoulay, after she served two four-year terms in office.

The organisation's general assembly must now ratify the 54-year-old Egyptologist's appointment during its meeting in Uzbekistan on November 6.

The body has never gone against a recommendation by the executive board, which is made up of 58 out of 194 member states.

Enany won 55 of the 57 votes cast, said the board's chair, Vera Lacoeuilhe.

The United States, which has announced its withdrawal from the organisation, did not take part in the vote.

Only two candidates were in the running for the top job, after a Mexican contender backed out in August.

Enany, who emerged as the favourite, faced off against the Republic of Congo's Firmin Edouard Matoko, who had served as UNESCO's de facto foreign minister until March.

Enany oversaw antiquities, and later also tourism, from 2016 to 2022 under President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.

Since announcing his bid more than two years ago, he claimed to have visited 65 countries, meeting 400 people over 30 months on the campaign trail.

If his nomination is confirmed, he will take office on November 14 as UNESCO's first director-general from an Arab country and the second from an African nation, after Senegal's Amadou Mahtar Mbow, who served from 1974 to 1987.

Enany would take the reins at a difficult time for UNESCO - best known for establishing world heritage sites - after the United States announced in June that it would leave the organisation, claiming it was biased against Israel and promoted "divisive" causes.

That move, set to take effect at the end of 2026, will deal a major blow to the agency's finances, as Washington contributes eight percent of its budget.

Enany has said he would seek to bring the United States back into the organisation.

In May, Nicaragua also announced it was pulling out of UNESCO after it bestowed its annual press prize on a venerable Nicaraguan newspaper whose staff were forced into exile.

(FRANCE 24 with AFP)

articles.personality_title: Egypt’s Khaled El-Enany chosen to lead UNESCO
articles.personality_presentation:

**What happened** – On October 1, 2025, UNESCO’s executive board voted almost unanimously to select Khaled El-Enany, a former Egyptian minister of tourism and antiquities, as the next director-general. He will replace the current leader after her two terms end. The full UNESCO membership will officially approve him in November.

**Impact** – El-Enany will be the first Arab and only the second African to lead UNESCO. His appointment marks a new step toward greater regional diversity in the organization’s leadership. He brings experience managing Egypt’s cultural sites and hopes to address current challenges, like financial losses from some countries leaving.

**What’s next step** – The UNESCO general assembly will meet in Uzbekistan in November to confirm El-Enany’s appointment. If confirmed, he will start his new role in mid-November and focus on rebuilding partnerships, including encouraging the United States to rejoin.

articles.personality_title_es: Khaled El-Enany de Egipto elegido para dirigir la UNESCO
articles.personality_presentation_es:
